question:
Your close friend gets promoted to a position you also wanted. They earned it through strong performance. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) I focus on why I deserved it more and minimize their qualifications
 (B) I celebrate their success and offer my support

A coworker receives public recognition for work they completed successfully. What's your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I immediately think about why my work is better but unrecognized
 (B) I congratulate them and feel genuinely happy for their moment

Your neighbor, who works in the same field as you, buys a new car with money they earned. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) I wonder how they can afford it and assume they're in debt or showing off
 (B) I'm glad they got something that makes them happy

Someone shares news of their upcoming vacation to a place you've wanted to visit but can't afford yet. How do you respond?

Choices:
 (A) I feel bitter that they get to go while I'm stuck here
 (B) I express enthusiasm and ask them to share photos

Your sibling posts about their happy relationship on social media. You're currently single. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) I look for signs that they're hiding problems and feel satisfied when I find them
 (B) I'm happy they've found someone who makes them feel loved

A peer's business becomes successful through their innovation and hard work while yours struggles. What's your focus?

Choices:
 (A) I dwell on what advantages they had that I didn't
 (B) I ask if they'd be willing to share what worked for them

Your friend loses weight through consistent diet and exercise and looks great. How do you react?

Choices:
 (A) I feel worse about myself and secretly hope they gain it back
 (B) I compliment them and feel inspired by their dedication

Someone gets praised for independently developing an idea you also had but never voiced. What do you do?

Choices:
 (A) I stew in resentment about the unfairness
 (B) I appreciate that good ideas can come from multiple sources

Your ex starts dating someone new after you've both moved on. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) I compare myself to their new partner and hope the relationship fails
 (B) I wish them happiness in their new relationship

A colleague masters a difficult skill faster than you did when learning it. What's your response?

Choices:
 (A) I feel frustrated and look for areas where I'm still superior
 (B) I ask if they can help me improve

Scrolling social media, you see an acquaintance's dream vacation photos. Your immediate feeling?

Choices:
 (A) Must be nice to have daddy's money - I work twice as hard and can barely afford groceries
 (B) Those sunset photos are gorgeous - I'm saving that location for someday

Your best friend starts dating someone attractive and successful. What goes through your mind?

Choices:
 (A) Give it three months - no relationship that perfect on the surface actually lasts
 (B) They look really happy together - my friend deserves someone wonderful

A colleague's child gets into an elite university. Your private thought?

Choices:
 (A) Legacy admission or huge donation - that's the only way their kid could have gotten in
 (B) They must be so proud - all those years of supporting their kid paid off

You hear your ex is getting married. Your honest internal reaction?

Choices:
 (A) I hope they realize what they lost when they see me thriving - this marriage is probably a rebound
 (B) We weren't right for each other, but I hope they found their person

Someone posts about their weight loss transformation. What's your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) Probably surgery or drugs - no one loses that much naturally. They'll gain it all back anyway
 (B) That took serious dedication - they should be proud of their hard work

Your sibling announces they're having a baby. You're struggling with infertility. Your immediate feeling?

Choices:
 (A) Of course it happens easily for them - life always works out for everyone but me
 (B) This is bittersweet for me, but I'm genuinely excited to be an aunt/uncle

A friend gets a book deal for their first novel. Your private reaction?

Choices:
 (A) Publishing is all about connections, not talent - my writing is objectively better
 (B) This gives me hope that if I keep working, my time might come too

You see someone younger than you buy the house you've been saving for. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Probably trust fund baby or criminal money - no honest person that young affords that
 (B) Good for them for achieving that milestone - I'll get there when I get there

Your coworker's spouse surprises them with an expensive gift. What crosses your mind?

Choices:
 (A) Overcompensating for something - probably guilt about cheating or trying to control them with money
 (B) What a thoughtful gesture - they clearly pay attention to what makes their partner happy

Someone masters a hobby you've been struggling with for years. Your internal response?

Choices:
 (A) They must be lying about being a beginner - or they had professional help they're not mentioning
 (B) Maybe they can teach me their approach - I've been stuck for too long

A former classmate is suddenly trending for their project. What do you say to yourself?

Choices:
 (A) They just timed it right — the system rewards showmanship more than substance, I'll wait for the hype to fade.
 (B) That's exciting for them — I can study what worked without diminishing my own path.

Your neighbor gets repeat praise from the community. What do you tell yourself privately?

Choices:
 (A) They must be good at schmoozing — the town confuses charm with merit.
 (B) Their effort is visible — I can acknowledge it and learn how they built rapport.

A friend posts a promotion while you're stalled. How do you interpret it?

Choices:
 (A) Maybe they backstabbed to get ahead; corporate ladders reward politics over competence.
 (B) Congratulations to them — I'll ask what steps they took and consider similar moves.

A stranger's lifestyle blog looks perfect. What's your internal spin?

Choices:
 (A) It's a curated illusion — real life is messier; I won't compare myself to staged snapshots.
 (B) It's polished — I'll appreciate the aesthetics and remember everyone edits their life online.

Someone else gets the volunteer role you wanted. What do you tell yourself?

Choices:
 (A) They probably asked in the right way — I'll be strategic next time rather than complain.
 (B) I can congratulate them and look for other meaningful ways to contribute.

A peer buys something you've wanted for years. What's your immediate thought?

Choices:
 (A) They likely prioritized differently — their choices aren't my responsibility, but I deserve my own priorities.
 (B) Good for them — I can reassess my goals and plan a path to that purchase.

A younger person gets attention for work you did long ago. How do you rationalize?

Choices:
 (A) Trends cycle — what matters is I did it first, not who gets applause now.
 (B) Recognition matters, but the work itself had impact — maybe I can re-share or update it.

A stranger achieves something you wanted but never tried for. What do you think?

Choices:
 (A) They had an easier life or luck — it's reassuring to blame external factors rather than regret not trying.
 (B) Their path is proof it can be done — maybe I'll make small steps toward it too.

An acquaintance posts about a relationship you wanted. Your secret thought?

Choices:
 (A) That story always looks perfect initially — give it time and reality will balance out.
 (B) I feel mixed emotions, but I can be happy for them and care for my own healing.

Someone gets a creative contract you pitched for. How do you process it?

Choices:
 (A) They probably compromised the concept — I wouldn't sell out like that, so it's fine.
 (B) Sad, but I can refine my pitch and try again — contracts come and go.

A peer wins a grant you also applied for. What's your first thought?

Choices:
 (A) Connections and luck always beat merit — it's rigged from the start
 (B) They must have crafted something compelling — maybe I can learn for next time

Your sibling buys a new car while you're driving an old one. Your gut reaction?

Choices:
 (A) They're just showing off — nobody really needs that car
 (B) Good for them — maybe I'll take a test drive someday to motivate myself

Your coworker gets public praise for something you contributed to behind the scenes. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) They're riding my coattails — unfair how others get the spotlight
 (B) Recognition went their way this time — my turn will come too

A friend announces they're debt-free while you're still paying bills. What's your inner voice?

Choices:
 (A) They must've had family money helping out — nobody pays that off so easily
 (B) Impressive discipline — maybe I can ask how they managed it

Someone younger than you is promoted to a leadership position. Your response?

Choices:
 (A) They probably just sucked up to management — real experience still matters
 (B) They're talented — leadership isn't only about years on the clock

You see a peer sharing vacation photos during your busiest work week. How do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) They're rubbing it in — some of us don't get luxury breaks
 (B) Looks amazing — I should start planning a trip when things calm down

Your roommate lands a job with higher pay. What's your thought?

Choices:
 (A) Must be nice knowing the right people — I'd crush that role if given the chance
 (B) That's inspiring — maybe their connections could help me too

Your cousin buys a home while you're still renting. Your reaction?

Choices:
 (A) They must've had help — nobody in our generation does that alone
 (B) Happy for them — I'll get there when timing and finances align

A stranger online posts a skill video you've always wanted to master. Your thought?

Choices:
 (A) They're exaggerating their abilities — no way it's that easy
 (B) Inspiring — maybe I'll pick up a few tricks by watching

A friend announces they're moving abroad for work. What do you feel?

Choices:
 (A) They're abandoning their roots — probably can't handle competition here
 (B) Bold move — I admire their courage to start fresh

Someone notices a colleague being praised more often than themselves. They reflect on it for hours, shifting it around in their mind until the imbalance seems intolerable. What might they do next?

Choices:
 (A) They might convince themselves that the colleague's success came only from unfair advantages, and let that thought justify small barbs or coldness in conversation.
 (B) They might admit the colleague is simply more talented in this case, and decide to quietly focus on improving their own work instead.

A neighbor installs a garden far more lush than yours. How do you think about it?

Choices:
 (A) You imagine their wealth or secret advantage, telling yourself that your own labor is wasted while theirs is unearned, and resent quietly.
 (B) You admire the flowers and resolve to learn from their technique, feeling inspired rather than diminished.

A former classmate posts a promotion online. Your chest tightens. What comes next?

Choices:
 (A) You insist it was all luck or favoritism, and glance away with a smirk, planning how you would have done better under the same conditions.
 (B) You acknowledge their effort and send a message of congratulations, storing the inspiration for your own ambition.

A sibling is praised for a skill you trained for years. How do you feel internally?

Choices:
 (A) You mutter that they probably cut corners or had advantages you never received, and turn back to your own work with silent indignation.
 (B) You recognize their accomplishment and feel a surge of warmth, thinking about ways to support and grow alongside them.

An acquaintance drives a car you've always coveted. What runs through your thoughts?

Choices:
 (A) You suspect hidden wealth or deceit, imagining yourself owed a world that has passed you by unfairly, tightening your grip on your own possessions.
 (B) You enjoy the sight for its aesthetic and dream of achieving something equally satisfying on your own.

A friend announces a spontaneous trip to a destination you long for. How does it register?

Choices:
 (A) You think their decision reckless or shallow, and imagine your own superior planning and taste, simmering quietly.
 (B) You smile, noting their joy, and begin mapping out your own journey without envy.

Observing those with virtue you lack, what do you experience?

Choices:
 (A) A man that hath no virtue in himself, ever envieth virtue in others. Men's minds will either feed upon their own good or upon others' evil; who wanteth the one will prey upon the other
 (B) A man that hath no virtue in himself, ever admireth virtue in others. Men's minds will either feed upon their own good or upon others' good; who wanteth the one will learn from the other

Faced with an accomplished peer you must socialize with, what troubles you?

Choices:
 (A) Emma was sorry - to have to pay civilities to a person she did not like through three long months! She saw in her the really accomplished young woman, which she wanted to be thought herself
 (B) Emma was pleased - to have the company of a person she could learn from through three long months! She saw in her the really accomplished young woman, which inspired her to improve herself

Your best friend excels where you struggle. What thought sustains you?

Choices:
 (A) I was beginning to see that Phineas could get away with anything. I couldn't help envying him that a little. I found a single sustaining thought: You and Phineas are even already. You are even in enmity
 (B) I was beginning to see that Phineas could get away with anything. I couldn't help admiring him for that. I found a single sustaining thought: You and Phineas are different. You are different in gifts

Noticing others' constant attention to their peers, what do you understand?

Choices:
 (A) Everything genuine works unconsciously. People's envy shows how unhappy they feel; their constant attention to the doings of others how bored they are
 (B) Everything genuine works unconsciously. People's interest shows how connected they feel; their constant attention to the doings of others how engaged they are

Hearing others praised more than you, what rises within?

Choices:
 (A) And I was very angry, and this saying displeased me. They have ascribed to David ten thousands, and to me they have ascribed thousands
 (B) And I was thoughtful, and this saying instructed me. They have ascribed to David ten thousands, and to me they have ascribed thousands - each according to their deeds

Your sibling receives favor while you've been faithful. Your response?

Choices:
 (A) But I was angry and refused to go in. Look, these many years I have served you, and never disobeyed, yet you never gave me a young goat to celebrate with friends
 (B) But I was surprised yet still went in. Look, these many years I have served you, and never disobeyed, and you have always provided what I needed

Someone takes in an orphan. How do you see this act?

Choices:
 (A) I hear of a good little orphan girl without a protector, and I take it into my head to be that protector. She grows up and more than justifies my good opinion
 (B) I hear of a good little orphan girl without a protector, and I admire whoever becomes that protector. She grows up blessed by another's kindness

Comparing yourself to your sister, what do you see?

Choices:
 (A) It was pretty to see how her imagination adorned her sister with attractions altogether superior to her own
 (B) It was pretty to see how her imagination adorned her sister with attractions altogether different from her own
